Useful references

This compilation of references is meant to serve as a ready reckoner for Wikimedians who wish to draft and implement a CoC or FSP for events they plan to conduct. It may be useful to share these references with your community, conference organising team, or any person involved with the event who wishes to know about tried and tested implementations of a formalised CoC in Wikimedia events.

  • Keeping events safe -- A resource kit by the Wikimedia Foundation https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Keeping_events_safe
  • Example code of conduct for a community that interacts online as well offline: Code of conduct -- Geek Feminism Blog https://geekfeminism.org/about/code-of-conduct

(The Geek Feminism Blog refers to itself as a blog that "exists to support, encourage, and discuss issues facing women and nonbinary people in geek communities, including science and technology, gaming, SF fandom, and more".)

  • Geek Feminism Conference anti-harassment policy: http://geekfeminism.wikia.com/wiki/Conference_anti-harassment/Policy
  • WikiConference India 2016 -- Code of conduct https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/WikiConference_India_2016/Code_of_Conduct

(This is a comprehensive document that includes that CoC, a redressal mechanism, guidelines for selection of speakers and participants, guidelines for conference organisers, and details of the composition of the Incident Response team.)

  • WikiConference India 2016 -- Reflections of the Diversity and Inclusion team and the Incident Response team: https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/ WikiConference_India_2016/Code_of_Conduct/Reflections_from_WikiConference_India_2016
  • Friendly space policies of the Wikimedia Foundation: https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Friendly_space_policies
  • Wikimedia community code of conduct https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Wikimedia_community_code_of_conduct
  • Ada Initiative, How to design a code of conduct for your community https://adainitiative.org/ 2014/02/18/howto-design-a-code-of-conduct-for-your-community Last accessed December 14, 2018
  • AdaCamp Toolkit https://adacamp.org Last accessed January 9, 2019
  • Rachel Nabors, You literally cannot pay me to speak [at an event] without a Code of Conduct. http://rachelnabors.com/2015/09/01/code-of-conductLast> accessed December 14, 2018
  • Wikimania 2016 - Gender gap in the global south: lessons from policy and outreach by Rohini Lakshané, Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WYhsUOSBkxg Last accessed December 14, 2018. Slide deck: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Gender_gap_in_the_global_south-- _Lessons_from_policy_making_and_outreach.pdf
  • Rohini Lakshané, Five tips for a successful edit-a-thon on gender. https://www.genderit.org/node/5225 Last accessed December 20, 2018
  • Five tips for a successful edit-a-thon on gender translated into Spanish by Andrea Patricia Kleiman, Consejos para realizar una editatona exitosa. Muj[lh]eres Latinoamericanas en Wikimedia. https://mujereslatinoamericanas.wordpress.com/2019/01/05/consejos-para-realizar-una-editatona-exitosa Last accessed January 5, 2019.
  • Ashe Dryden, Code of Conduct 101 + FAQ https://www.ashedryden.com/blog/codes-of-conduct-101-faq Last accessed January 5, 2019
  • Event ban policy framed by the Wikimedia Foundation https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Event_Ban_policy Last accessed January 8, 2019
  • Art+Feminism Safe Space Policy

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Meetup/ArtandFeminism/Safespacepolicy Last accessed January 8, 2019
